title: IPV4 & IPV6
question: /past_papers/chapter_2_2/question_1753862769608.png
solution:
Length of the Address:
IPv4 addresses are 32 bits long, typically written as four octets (e.g., 192.168.0.1).
IPv6 addresses are 128 bits long, written as eight groups of four hexadecimal digits (e.g., 2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334).
Address Space:
IPv4 provides a limited number of addresses (around 4.3 billion), which has led to address shortages.
IPv6 offers an extremely large address space (around 340 undecillion addresses), which allows for an almost unlimited number of unique IP addresses.
These differences are among the key reasons IPv6 was developed to overcome the limitations of IPv4.

title: subnet
question: /past_papers/chapter_2_2/question_1753982237206.png
solution:
Faster Network: Splits traffic, so the network runs smoother with less congestion.
Better Security: Keeps sensitive areas separate, like guest Wi-Fi from company devices.
Easier Management: Smaller groups of devices are simpler to monitor and fix.
Saves IP Addresses: Uses only the IP addresses needed for each group.
Room to Grow: Adding new devices or departments is easier with subnets.
Organized Setup: Groups devices by purpose or location, making things tidy.

title: router & URL
question: /past_papers/chapter_2_2/question_1754020321451.png
solution:
Receives packets from devices

Performed by the router

The router receives data packets from connected devices (e.g., computers, phones). This is a core function of a router, acting as an intermediary to handle incoming packets and decide their next destination.
Finds the IP address of a Uniform Resource Locator (URL)

Not performed by the router

Resolving a URL to an IP address is done by a DNS server, not the router. The routerâ€™s role is to forward packets based on known IP addresses, while DNS servers translate domain names (e.g., www.example.com) into IP addresses (e.g., 192.0.2.1).
Directs each packet to all devices attached to it

Not performed by the router

A router does not broadcast packets to all connected devices. Instead, it selectively forwards packets to the correct device or network based on the destination IP address. Broadcasting to all devices is typical of a hub, not a router.
Stores the IP and/or MAC address of all devices attached to it

Performed by the router

Routers maintain an ARP table (Address Resolution Protocol table) that maps the IP addresses and MAC addresses of connected devices. This table helps the router accurately forward packets within the local network.
